thread.title: Jakarta urged to scrap ad-hoc permit allocation system for live cattle imports
thread.title_full: Jakarta urged to scrap ad-hoc permit allocation system for live cattle imports

author: Jared Lynch
title: Jakarta urged to scrap ad-hoc permit allocation system for live cattle imports
text:
Australian cattle producers have called on Jakarta to scrap its ad-hoc permit allocation system for the importation of live cattle, saying it's making meat more expensive in Indonesia.
Indonesian authorities have implemented emergency measures – issuing permits for another 50,000 animals from Australia – to combat rising beef prices and protests from consumers and butchers.
It comes after Indonesia – which accounts for about 56 per cent of Australia's $1.3 billion live export market – shocked exporters and beef farmers last month when it said it would only take 50,000 head of cattle this quarter, down from 250,000 for the same period in 2014.
Alison Penfold, chief executive of the Australian Livestock Exporters Council, said the Indonesian government must move to an annual permit allocation system.
Ms Penfold said issuing permits quarterly and on a spot basis fuelled rising beef prices.
"The government is saying that they want to stabilise prices but the manner in which the permits are being issued has an inflationary effect," she said.
"If you move to an annualised system you're better allowing the market signals to be properly interpreted and respond according ... removing those unnecessary price burdens potentially."
Ms Penfold said her organisation and members were yet to receive official confirmation from Indonesia, including how many extra cattle would be required, their weight specification, delivery timeframes and who the permits would be issued to.
It is understood Indonesia is seeking slaughter rather than feeder cattle so it can immediately meet consumer demand. Slaughter cattle have already been fattened up and are ready to be killed, as opposed to feeder cattle which are kept in a feedlot in their destination country until they reach the required weight for slaughter.
Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association chief executive Tracey Hayes, who is in Jakarta, also supported a shift to an annualised shifting of permits because it gave some certainty to both Indonesian customers and Australian cattle producers and exporters.
Ms Hayes said it may be challenging to source the additional 50,000 head of cattle and ones that are ready for slaughter.
"It is difficult managing the logistics in the paddock but also for the shippers and exporters. A lot of the ships have been deployed to other jobs now," she said.
"Some of our slaughter product has been going into Vietnam. It's more difficult to source at short notice and further reinforces our position that there is merit in pursuing an annual permit allocation system.
"It would provide a level assurance to both Indonesia and Australia. It would enable our members to position themselves to be able to meet the demand and supply in a timely manner."
Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce called on Jakarta last month to introduce an annual permit issuing system after it slashed import numbers for the quarter.
"The quarterly quota system brings a form of uncertainty. An uncertainty in price from Jakarta and supply from Australia and in any business you've got to look further down the supply chain," Mr Joyce said.
